Re: License #: CB820201485
Dear Ms. Hayes:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/26/2024. An exit conference was held with your agency on 10/1/2024 Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing on the CWL-4617 Acknowledgement
of appeal rights. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must notify this
office in writing and an administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even if you contest the
issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action
plan.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan modification of the agency license
from a provisional license to a regular license is recommended.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

(1) An agency shall ensure and document all the

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans(CAP) during this
licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency's 2023 Interim inspection
which was completed on 1/4/2024, with the CAP approved on 5/8/2024. During
that Interim inspection the agency received 37 rule violations. It was the findings
in the Interim inspection which resulted in the agency’s current provisional
licensing status.
During this Renewal inspection the agency received 21 rule violations (a decrease
from the 37 it received during the 2023 Interim inspection) of which 14 are repeat
violation (12 are specific repeats from 2023). The agency’s CAP compliance
around the 12 rule violations is as follows: with the exception of ADM 330 for
Adoption quarterly progress reports, where the number of individual cases cited
increased from 2 of 6 (for its open cases) to 6 of 7; and R400.12420(1)(g) for
Updated service plans and FOM-801-3 for Medical passports, where the number
of individual cases cited stayed the same (2 of 6 and 3 of 8 respectively); and the
remaining 11 violations showed slight deceases. Rules R400.12405(5)(a) &(b) for
Change of placement and R400.12212(3)(a) for Personnel records showed the
highest decreases, from 6 of 8 to 2 of 6 and from 8 of 26 to 3 of 21 respectively for
the number of individual cases cited. Continued staff turnover; and therein the
need to train and get staff acclimated to all requirements impacted the agency’s
rule/policy compliances and contributed to repeat violations.
Electronic and or physical documents/tools we reviewed for verification of CAP
compliance and the above reporting showed that the agency made some
progress on its CAP. It was not totally successful with all aspects of the CAP, as
some repeat violations occurred. The agency continues to be impacted by staff
turnover and inexperienced line staff. The agency was upfront related to its
continued staffing challenges; and they report they are working to correct this.
They continue to remain on pause from taking any new foster care cases. They
also reported currently having two workers attending the child welfare training
institute (CWTI) and they are seeking to hire four other workers(two have been
identified ). Once the two workers currently attending CWTI completes the training
and passes the test, in the coming weeks, these staff will enable the agency’s
caseload count to come into compliance.
13

The agency's second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2024SIC0001106 where the complaint was received on 2/2/2024. The allegation
was that an agency staff falsified records. The special investigation found the
agency in noncompliance of PA 116. 722.120 (c) for not providing accurate and
truthful information to the department. The agency submitted an acceptable
corrective plan on 4/2/2024. The agency provided information showing they
implemented and completed this corrective action plan.
The agency has two other special investigations underway:
Special investigation 2024SIC0001794 related to a complaint received on
9/23/2024. The complaint alleged the director is not approving 3130A's when
children have been placed in the home. Additionally, that there are missing 1643's
and that the agency is over caseload compliance. The special investigation
findings are pending.
Special investigation 2025SIC0000001 related to complaints received on
10/1/2024. The complaints alleged the director asked staff to enter false
information to include a sibling contact; the director is not following the treatment
foster care contracts; allows untrained staff to hold the treatment cases, and the
director is unfamiliar with policies. Additionally, that an agency staff may have
falsified signatures and dates on treatment plans and other documentations. The
special investigation findings are pending.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a Chief Administrator’s report dated 9/17/2024. The report
was reviewed, and it addressed an assessment of the prior inspection rule
noncompliance and other aspects as required by this report. The chief
administrator, who is new to the position, but not the agency, reported some
improvement on the CAP and noted that systemic staff turnover/shortages were
barriers to the CAP’s full implementation or completion. She reported an increased
in 10 out of 11 KPI (Key Performance Indicators) across the board from 1/1/2024-
8/31/2024. She acknowledged that though an increase was seen in this data from
the previous reporting period, some goals fell below the required performance
expectation, but the trending was still upward. The chief administrator reported
the agency will continue their efforts to improve in all rule and contractual
requirement areas.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a 2024 annual budget and end of December 2023 and
2022 independent financial audit. Neither report showed any noticeable significant
areas of concern.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator and at least four other
administrative team members, one foster care worker, one licensing worker, one
independent living youth worker, one adoption worker, and one supervisor was
interviewed. The reporting from the staff members on the agency’s strengths
14

were that the agency feeds them well at meetings, tells them they are appreciated;
and gives incentive for caseload oversizing, if that occurs. Additionally, the agency
is upfront about its CAP issues/need to improve. Administration tries to help staff.
Supervisors/administration give staff weekly reminders of what needs to be
done/due dates, and the agency goes over and beyond to get resources for
families. Area of growth cited by the staff members included a need for less
micro-managing of staff members who do not have issues, not expecting workers
to work “24/7” just because administrators do, more staff team building activities,
less staff turnover, better acknowledgement of a staff when progress/positive
actions have been achieved, and standardization of some tasks and standards.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency’s site did not reveal any areas of concern. The
agency appeared to have adequate space and equipment for its staff; and case
records were properly stored.
VII. AGENCY ANALYST FINDINGS
The Division of Child Welfare Licensing Agency Analyst reported two safety alerts
for the agency this inspection.
Alert #1 from an unlicensed relative home visits on 8/28/2024:
Concern:
The unlicensed relative’s home did not have operable smoke detectors on each level
of occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. Nor did the home have an operable
carbon monoxide detector.
Resolution:
The agency reported the agency now has smoke detectors on every level, and a
carbon monoxide detector. The agency provided photos showing the devices
installed.
Concern:
A foster child occupied a room in the basement which does not have a window that
is large enough to be used for egress.
Resolution:
The agency reported the youth’s sleeping space was moved to a bedroom, and the
youth is sleeping on a full-size bunkbed. Photos were provided showing the
room/space.
Alert # 2 from an unlicensed relative home visit on 9/10/2024:
Concern:
An unlicensed relative’s home did not have an operable smoke detector on each
level of occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. Nor did the home have an
operable carbon monoxide detector.
15

Resolution:
The agency purchased smoke detectors and a carbon monoxide detector for the
caregiver. The assigned worker helped the caregiver to install the detectors. Photos
were provided showing the installations.

Up receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the agency’s
license be modification to a second provisional.
